15.00.text:
The Parliamentary Archives holds over four
million records that contain the

19.30.text:
collection of documentary evidence from
both the House of Commons and House of Lords.

25.00.text:
There are around 64,000 original
acts of Parliament on parchment and we

30.28.text:
have format materials that contain
audio-visual right up to the present day

34.63.text:
as well as parchment seals, paper
manuscripts and printed books.

41.70.text:
We have a small dedicated team that work to
digitise the collection and my team in

47.80.text:
particular, the conservators, help to
prepare items and support that service.

52.27.text:
The reason why we can't digitise the whole
collection is because it would take

56.14.text: decades to manage the whole process.

58.72.text:
It would also be very costly. 
We also have all sorts of shapes and sizes in

62.86.text:
our collections that would take an awful
lot of time to manage in the process.

68.57.text:
No major library or archive has managed to
digitise more than five percent of their

73.34.text:
collection and digitisation has been
going on for many many years.

81.74.text:
When we receive a request for
digitisation, the first thing we do is

85.76.text: retrieve the item from the repository.

88.73.text:
We may need to call in collection care,
this is my team, to look at any stabilisation needs.

95.30.text:
The collection care
check is really to check the condition

98.09.text:
of the item before it is going to be
photographed. The problem we have is we

103.28.text:
do have a lot of collections that are
actually in very good condition but you

106.13.text:
also have some collections in very poor
condition and that would mean there'd be

109.82.text:
cuts and tears, it might be very dirty,
there are losses. Before the photographic

114.38.text:
process occurs, which is also a risk to
the collection if the item isn't stablised,

119.60.text: we have to make those repairs.

122.65.text:
Once we've done all our checks and we're
happy that the item is stabilised enough

127.78.text:
for photography, we hand it over to the
digitisation team.

133.65.text:
So once I've received the document, 
I setup my workstation.

139.19.text:
I'll make sure my camera's level, turn on
the lights and turn on the computer.

142.97.text:
We have a sort of array of equipment
that we can use to help us get the best

148.22.text:
The public has an expectation nowadays
to view images online and we need to

157.10.text:
There's a complete array of
documents in the archive.

162.29.text:
Some are very simple to photograph,
some are rather more complex.

166.01.text:
We do have some very large documents,
which will be made up of hundreds of

170.18.text:
images and it will take a long time to
photograph them all. But we don't want to do

174.26.text:
it very often because they're fragile so
it's worth doing correctly once.

180.70.text:
One of the great benefits of
digitisation is that we can upload

184.70.text:
images onto the internet and they are
viewable around the world.

191.18.text:
It is important that we digitise these
documents because they are historically

196.40.text:
Digitisation isn't the end of the
process. The challenge today is that we still

200.15.text:
have to store and archive these images
for the future.
